qas.question: What describes communication as creative and dynamic rather than discrete?
Who theorized that the types of media people use to communicate will offer different possibilities for the shape of society?
What ancient civilization did Harold Innis use as an example of his theory?
What did Harold Innis call papyrus?
What did Space Binding make possible for the ancient Egyptian civilizations?

answers.text: transmission of written orders across space, empires

qas.question: Wark and McKenzie had a theory that people use different types of what to communicate?
Ancient Rome was the famous example of the theory of whom?
Using the media to water, people can change and shape communication where?
Describing communication as a creative but not a dynamic continuous process is the definition of what?

plausible_answers.text: the shape and durability of society

qas.question: Using the same media for communication will offer possibilities for what?

context: <a0_0><b8_0>Theories of coregulation<b8_0/><a0_0/> describe communication as a creative and dynamic continuous process, rather than a discrete exchange of information. Canadian <b5_0>media<b5_0/> scholar <a1_0><b6_0>Harold Innis<b6_0/><a1_0/> had the theory that people use different types of media to communicate and which one they choose to use will offer different possibilities for <b9_0>the shape and durability of society<b9_0/> (Wark, McKenzie 1997). His famous example of this is using ancient <a2_0>Egypt<a2_0/> and looking at the ways they built themselves out of media with very different properties stone and papyrus. Papyrus is what he called '<a3_0>Space Binding<a3_0/>'. it made possible the <a4_0>transmission of written orders across space, empires<a4_0/> and enables the waging of distant military campaigns and colonial administration. The other is stone and 'Time Binding', through the construction of temples and the pyramids can sustain their authority generation to generation, through this media they can change and shape communication <b7_0>in their society<b7_0/> (Wark, McKenzie 1997).
